fullText:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/lempicka-review-broadway-musical-eden-espinosa-rachel-chavkin-519b3aca

Eden Espinosa Photo: Matthew MurphyNew York

“Never let them see your brushstrokes,” admonishes the title character, the painter Tamara de Lempicka, in the Broadway musical based on her life. Unhappily, “Lempicka” often seems to be all visible brushstrokes, a neatly constructed but surprisingly conventional show that turns the wild, imperious and wayward woman into a fairly standard-issue heroine, enduring trauma and searching for lasting love while also trying to assert her identity as an artist.

llmScore.reasoning: [ensemble-majority] | 2/3 models agree: Negative | Claude: The critic uses clearly negative language like 'unhappily,' describes the show as 'surprisingly conventional,' and calls the visuals 'a hodgepodge,' indicating disappointment with the production's execution and artistic choices. | GPT-4o: The review criticizes the show for being conventional and visually disorganized, suggesting it does not live up to its potential or the subject's complexity. | Gemini: The review highlights both positive aspects (neatly constructed) and negative aspects (conventional). The overall tone suggests a mixed experience, not strongly recommending or discouraging.
